Two years ago I had the honor of

in Mountain View and my mother

So I thought, why don't

174.text:
My mom was at the

been given her first iPad ever.

And her favorite thing

and look up all the extremely

So she was excited

And before I gave

200.text:
And my mom is usually a very

206.text:
And I just thought she
was bored out of her mind.

209.text:
Then we were taken to

214.text:
like the main

220.text: And my mom's face lit up.

222.text:
I could see she was

228.text:
And then when she found
out that food was free

233.text:
And you know, I think she went

a couple of times and shoved

241.text: So after lunch I gave my talk.

242.text:
And then there was

244.text:
And as I sat at the

246.text:
for this long line of
people, I could see my mom

249.text:
going up and down the

252.text:
And I was thinking,
what on earth

257.text:
Like, is she trying to get some

261.text: Or find out more about cancer?

263.text:
And then as the line

266.text:
And she was saying, to
everyone, excuse me,

271.text:
could you find my
son a job here?

282.text:
So after we left

291.text:
You could use the

And I will finally,
finally be proud of you.

John Chu and I really quickly

463.text:
The both of us

465.text:
that immigrated from Asia,

468.text:
The simple fact is
that Asian men--

470.text:
not just in the US,

472.text:
are raised from a
really early age

474.text:
to focus on excelling in

479.text:
So to go to the best

484.text:
So if you're a good looking,

489.text:
likely going to be

492.text:
or working at Goldman Sachs,

I mean, I can see

498.text:
out here that could

So that was very

508.text:
And there is little to no
support for Asian boys growing

514.text:
up to ever become actors,
writists, dancers, you know--

520.text:
And in fact, I think
telling your Asian parents

522.text:
you want to go into
acting is probably

524.text:
worse than telling them that
you got your teacher pregnant--

531.text:
So this goes back to
my mom and her quest

534.text:
for me to work at

537.text:
Yes, there's a part of her
that's so proud of me that

541.text:
she sees on book
shelves at Barnes Noble.

543.text:
Or like gets angry at them when

546.text:
But I truly believe she would

550.text:
up and told her tomorrow, hey,
I'm going to go to law school.

554.text:
That's just the
plain fact of it.

556.text:
So for me, leading a creative
life for the past two decades--

559.text:
going to journalism school,

562.text:
making experimental films

566.text:
All that has been a

569.text:
Quiet rebellion, but a

607.text:

937.text:

966.text:

I think Asians who

979.text:
as Asians who grew
up in America.

Since they grew up
not in the minority,

984.text:
they had a sense of themselves
that wasn't compromised.

988.text:
And that observation for me
was sort of an aha moment.

992.text:
I mean, I moved from
Singapore when I was 11

994.text:
and I had grown up
in a world where

995.text: I was part of the ruling class.

997.text:
So I never realized
how much help that was,

1000.text:
having that beginning
in Asia that helped me

1004.text: when I moved to the US.

1006.text:
And I think, really, I
would have never dared

1008.text:

Asians" if I'd grown up here.

1013.text:

more movies, TV shows, books,

1019.text:
into the world featuring

1023.text:
not just Asians,

1026.text:

new generations
